Entropy \u2013 Recognizing disorder's";

json.aline_00279_A.clio = "Revised Definition (Topic):Data\nThe original definition provided was straightforward enough, defining \"data\" simply as information processed electronically. However, upon further contemplation, here are some alternative ways to approach its definition while still incorporating relevant technical aspects:\n1. Digital Fossils: In today's digital age, data can also refer to the virtual remains left behind after something has passed away online. Think about all those abandoned social media accounts, lost passwords, forgotten blog posts \u2013 they may not hold sentimental value anymore, yet they remain there, silently accruing bits and bytes until someone decides to give them proper burial. So too do databases store precious metadata, even when applications themselves vanish without trace. These digital fossils offer glimpses into what once existed, serving both nostalgia and historiography purposes.\n2. Information Nexus: At heart, though, 'data' refers to anything capable of being represented digitally \u2013 whether it originated organically (e.g., text documents) or synthetically (e.g., machine-generated content).
